awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Uncertainty Propagation and Data Assimilation for Toxic Cloud Prediction
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award focuses on developing mathematical tools for accurate characterization and propagation of uncertainty in mathematical models, and fusion of model output with sparse, noisy data to determine estimates of the actual physical phenomenon and statistical measure of confidence in those estimates.  The principal goals of this CAREER award are twofold: (i) to understand how the uncertainty of input variables and the random forcing of winds affect the output of the dispersion model, and (ii) to provide a prediction of toxic cloud movement, together with quantitative measures of confidence in that prediction.  Uncertainty analysis of dispersion of toxic clouds is becoming one of the most important components for timely and accurate threat assessment from natural or man-made incidents (such as Chernobyl or Eyjafjallajökull incidents). Consequent to the toxic material release, response organizations and industries make decisions based on predictions of the cloud motion, with little knowledge or appreciation of the reliability of those predictions. The quantitative understanding of uncertainty is essential when predictions are to be used to inform policy making or mitigation solutions where significant resources are at stake. For example, an understanding of uncertainty in model predictions can play an essential role in the acceptance of the need to vacate a city in case of toxic material release where the cost of different choices varies by millions of dollars and human lives. 

If successful, this research work will provide means for evaluating hazard risks in space and time. An important practical outcome will be the ability to generate toxic material hazard maps.  This CAREER project also integrates educational outreach efforts into the research plan with the goal to increase the diversity and the number of students from minority groups in science and engineering in association with existing programs on campus. In addition, the PI will design a ``Self-Help'' tutorial web-site to inform and educate both students and researchers about nonlinear filtering and uncertainty characterization concepts. Research and education accomplishments completed, as part of the plan will be described in journal publications, and conference presentations.

por.por_cntn:
Natural and man-made disasters disasters such as the Deepwater Horizon oil-spill, Eyjafjallajokull eruption in Iceland, algae growth in great lakes, hurricane Katrina, and the Fukushima nuclear incident caused an avalanche of ripple effects, disrupting the nominal environmental, financial, and social systems. An accurate hazard map of the toxic material dispersion and multi-hypothesis forecasting is a first step towards timely containment of toxic agents and appropriate disaster management.

Computer simulations along with sophisticated mathematical models are used to study such complex dynamical systems. Such simulators can be extremely complex and stochastic in nature due to uncertainty attributable to errors in model parameters, model truncation and stochastic input. On other hand, observational data is limited in terms of the sampling rate and the limited access to the actual quantity of interest. The fusion of observational data with numerical simulation promises to provide greater understanding of physical phenomenon than either approach alone can achieve. An effective model-data fusion is contingent upon addressing research challenges, which include characterizing and propagating non-Gaussian uncertainties for large scale nonlinear systems, assimilating high dimensional noisy data with forecast model states, build an agnostic characteristic with regards to computational cost by deploying it in the cloud and incorporating the next generation of mobile sensors (such as drones) as both big data collection and processing units.

The crux of this research effort lies in accounting for uncertainties in model parameters of systems driven by stochastic input, which allows the computation of information theoretic metrics for dynamic sensing. This award has led to the development of computationally scalable algorithms to accurately propagate probability density function through nonlinear system flow through minimal number of simulations of computational model. Stochastic collocation methods in conjunction with novel non-product quadrature schemes developed my research groups were used to compute a probabilistic spatial-temporal estimate of ash presence during the April 2010 eruption of the Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland. Furthermore, these uncertainty propagation algorithms are used in an information theoretic framework to make decisions regarding where and when to collect sensor observations for better forecasting. Importantly, the developed algorithms are independent of the numerical simulation model, so the framework for prediction and uncertainty analysis can be directly applied to various applications. Besides improving the ability to forecast and represent the associated uncertainty of plumes, this work also has the potential to impact forecasting of other spatio-temporal phenomena such as spread of pandemic, algae blooms, traffic flow, space debris mitigation, etc.
